Sure, here's a possible episode that might fit the prompt:

One day, the Teacher was approached by a group of fundamentalist Christians who were concerned that his message was anti-Christian. They had listened to his teachings and noticed that he hadn't talked much about Jesus and God. They said that his teachings sounded too Eastern and not in line with Christian doctrine.

The Teacher listened to their concerns, and then he began to respond.

"I understand your concerns," the Teacher said. "But let me tell you a story about a Christian mystic named Meister Eckhart."

The Christians listened, and the Teacher continued.

"Meister Eckhart once said, 'The eye with which I see God is the same eye with which God sees me.' What he meant was that our perception of God is intimately connected with God's perception of us."

The Christians looked puzzled, and the Teacher continued.

"God is not an object that we can grasp or comprehend," the Teacher said. "God is a mystery that we can only experience through our own awareness and perception. When we cultivate curiosity and resilience, we open ourselves up to the mystery of God, and we become more aware of the divine presence in all things."

The Christians still looked skeptical, and the Teacher continued.

"Jesus himself said, 'The kingdom of God is within you,'" the Teacher said. "What he meant was that the divine presence is not limited to any particular place or time. It is within each of us, waiting to be discovered through our own awareness and perception."

The Christians listened to the Teacher's words, and then they began to nod with understanding. They realized that the Teacher's message was not anti-Christian, but rather a deepening of their own faith. They thanked the Teacher for his insights and walked away, feeling more curious and resilient than before.
